articles.headline: F.D.I.C. Sues Ex-Chief of Big Bank That Failed
articles.snippet: The chief, Kerry Killinger, and two other executives were accused of reckless lending practices that led to the collapse of the nation’s largest savings bank.
articles.abstract: The chief, Kerry Killinger, and two other executives were accused of reckless lending practices that led to the collapse of the nation’s largest savings bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation sued the former chief executive of Washington Mutual and two of his top lieutenants, accusing them of reckless lending before the 2008 collapse of what was the nation’s largest savings bank.

articles.headline: Japan’s Meltdown and the Global Economy’s
articles.snippet: The financial crisis that began in the United States and the nuclear crisis in Japan share a similar narrative: overconfidence born of experience led to increased risks when disaster struck.
articles.abstract: The financial crisis that began in the United States and the nuclear crisis in Japan share a similar narrative: overconfidence born of experience led to increased risks when disaster struck.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four years ago, there were fears of a financial meltdown — a term borrowed from the nuclear power industry. Now there are fears of a real meltdown.

articles.headline: Crisis Prompts Exodus of Executives From Tokyo
articles.snippet: Japan’s nuclear crisis has prompted a steady departure of business executives from Tokyo, with many heading to Osaka, Fukuoka or other cities farther from the damaged reactors.
articles.abstract: Japan’s nuclear crisis has prompted a steady departure of business executives from Tokyo, with many heading to Osaka, Fukuoka or other cities farther from the damaged reactors.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The crisis at the nuclear power plant 140 miles north of here is leading to a steady but orderly departure of business executives from Tokyo. Foreigners in particular are among those leaving, as concerns grow about the possibility of a catastrophic release of radiation and governments urge their citizens to consider seeking safety elsewhere in Japan or overseas.
articles.byline: By David Jolly and Ken Belson

articles.headline: Lacking Parts, G.M. Will Close Plant
articles.snippet: The company said a plant in Shreveport, La., which has 800 employees and makes two pickup trucks, would be closed next week.
articles.abstract: The company said a plant in Shreveport, La., which has 800 employees and makes two pickup trucks, would be closed next week.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — General Motors said Thursday that it would temporarily shut a truck plant in Louisiana because it could not get enough Japanese-made parts, the first in what analysts say could be widespread disruptions at auto plants in North America because of the earthquake, tsunami and nuclear crisis half a world away.

articles.headline: Radiation Spread Seen; Frantic Repairs Go On
articles.snippet: The first readings from American data-collection flights over the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in Japan show that the worst contamination has not spread beyond the 19-mile range of highest concern established by Japanese authorities.
articles.abstract: The first readings from American data-collection flights over the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in Japan show that the worst contamination has not spread beyond the 19-mile range of highest concern established by Japanese authorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The first readings from American data-collection flights over the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in northeastern Japan show that the worst contamination has not spread beyond the 19-mile range of highest concern established by Japanese authorities.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: As U.N. Backs Military Action in Libya, U.S. Role Is Unclear
articles.snippet: The Security Council on Thursday authorized measures to protect Libyan civilians from forces loyal to Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi, but the U.S. military might confine itself to a supporting role.
articles.abstract: The Security Council on Thursday authorized measures to protect Libyan civilians from forces loyal to Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi, but the U.S. military might confine itself to a supporting role.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations Security Council voted Thursday to authorize military action, including airstrikes against Libyan tanks and heavy artillery and a no-fly zone, a risky foreign intervention aimed at averting a bloody rout of rebels by forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
articles.byline: By Dan Bilefsky and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Radiation Fears and Distrust Push Thousands From Homes
articles.snippet: The spreading panic is caused in part by distrust that the Japanese government is telling the full truth about the nuclear accidents and how widespread the danger is.
articles.abstract: The spreading panic is caused in part by distrust that the Japanese government is telling the full truth about the nuclear accidents and how widespread the danger is.
articles.lead_paragraph: YAMAGATA, Japan — Neither last week’s earthquake, nor the tsunami that followed, nor days without electricity, water or heat could drive 70-year-old Sadako Shiga from her home. What finally caused her to flee was something invisible, but to her mind far more sinister: radiation.

articles.headline: Group of 7 to Intervene to Stabilize Yen’s Value
articles.snippet: The leading industrial nations will intervene in currency exchange markets to stop the rise of the yen and help Japan’s export markets.
articles.abstract: The leading industrial nations will intervene in currency exchange markets to stop the rise of the yen and help Japan’s export markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and other major industrial nations will join Japan in a highly unusual effort to stabilize the value of the yen by intervening in currency markets, the Group of 7 nations announced Thursday night.

articles.headline: Funds Find Opportunities in Volatility
articles.snippet: Alphabet Management is finding price discrepancies and making big bets by trading on them.
articles.abstract: Alphabet Management is finding price discrepancies and making big bets by trading on them.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Jason Adler, it doesn’t matter whether the market goes up. Or down. What matters is that it goes.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Louise Story

articles.headline: Bullets Stall Youthful Push for Arab Spring
articles.snippet: The movement for change in the Arab world is not necessarily over, but it has run up against dictators willing to use lethal force to preserve their power.
articles.abstract: The movement for change in the Arab world is not necessarily over, but it has run up against dictators willing to use lethal force to preserve their power.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANAMA, Bahrain — These days, Muhammad al-Maskati is a prisoner in his apartment, his BlackBerry shut off by the government, the streets outside his apartment filled with tanks, the hospitals around town packed with the wounded.

articles.headline: Obama Warns Libya, but Attacks Go On
articles.snippet: President Obama set forth non-negotiable conditions that he said Libya must immediately meet to avoid military action to enforce a no-flight zone and block attacks by the regime on civilians and rebels.
articles.abstract: President Obama set forth non-negotiable conditions that he said Libya must immediately meet to avoid military action to enforce a no-flight zone and block attacks by the regime on civilians and rebels.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday ordered Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to carry out an immediate cease-fire, withdraw his forces from rebel-held cities and stop all attacks on Libyan civilians or face military action from the United States and its allies in Europe and the Arab world.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Dozens of Protesters Are Killed in Yemen
articles.snippet: The largest protest so far in Yemen came under violent and sustained attack in the center of the capital, Sana.
articles.abstract: The largest protest so far in Yemen came under violent and sustained attack in the center of the capital, Sana.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — Yemen’s pro-democracy protests exploded into violence on Friday, as government supporters opened fire on demonstrators in this capital, killing at least 45 people and wounding more than 200. The bloodshed failed to disperse the angry throng of tens of thousands of protesters, the largest seen so far in a month of demonstrations calling for the ouster of President Ali Abdullah Saleh.
articles.byline: By Laura Kasinof and Robert F. Worth
